1_1H8x2Aeu28Lnj6vhXFNZ32kpvGS6dnqWGA.body:
It's potentially really cool. But I don't know how trustworthy it is to use over tor (or i2p) while retaining anonymity. I'm also leery about how every site needs to run js (it can't be helped, i guess!) Some of the developer posts on github also lead me to believe that this anonymity and security is not a very high priority to them.

Everything also seems to be set up to use only one identity on all sites. The identity it asked me to post on here is the same I used on ZeroMe and ZeroMail and everywhere else that required an identity (even an anonymous imageboard!) I don't know if I can even make a new one without deleting my entire ZeroNet profile and starting over. It seems I can only be one person on ZeroNet, which is counter to the way people participate on the public internet.

Very mixed feelings, but its still neat that I can publish something, send it to a bunch of peers, turn my computer off, and people will still access it. It's like freenet but not ancient. Everything about the UI is hipster millennial garbage though.

I've only been using it for a couple of days and that's what I think about ZeroNet so far.

> [gremious](#comment_13_1H8x2Aeu28Lnj6vhXFNZ32kpvGS6dnqWGA): You can use multiple identities, all you have to do is
That sounds really complicated!
It's frustrating that, in the software's default 'this-is-how-people-should-use-what-we-made' state, the ability to have two different identities has been disabled. It's like they're saying people SHOULDN'T be doing that.
Maybe it's just culture shock for me since I've always gravitated toward services where I can click a button and generate a new id. And maybe the way this function works will change over the course of the software's development.

5_1PTaJe3LLeB5Pfxq8KjcpQSPcSK1PQqsQs.body:
ZeroRadio would be cool. i dont think ZeroNet can support something like a live audio stream. maybe the music is all user contributed? maybe with an html player that tries to keep everyone listening roughly in synch somehow?

it might be cool to see some multiplayer games designed to take advantage of ZeroNet's functionality. chess, anyone? or perhaps even something as ambitious as a mud? maybe one of those collaborative drawing things?

i'd like to see people share interactive fiction. twine games are literally just an html file, easy as hell to share as optional files i would think

i'd like to see development on irc-like live chat rooms, like ZeroBoard or ZeroChat Live, and to see people actually active on them ;-;

i'd like to see continue development on ZeroMe. i don't have anything specific in mind. but it's already almost as cool as diaspora. and it's definitely much better than twister. it's probably the single best thing that has come out of ZeroNet.

this is a non-comprehensive list of things i'd like to see.

if people want to have a distributed network with persistent content which is quickly accessible, they need to develop a culture of giving up that bandwith or their precious hdd space in order to make that network happen.

this is a social problem and not a technical one, which hampers the growth of pretty much any decentralized service. it cannot be resolved with clever code. people need to learn to share and give back.

sounds like a good subject for a new post, brainstorming how to foster a culture of sharing and contributing resources.
hey, that qualifies as content we'd like to see!

1513417002_1EQuGEmS5J8SQ1xA6MM9KfubBb71u.body:
if you don't want to host something you don't have to. delete it on zero hello. does it host illegal content? then add it to your black list. that isn't hard.

0chan and 0chan Porn are two different sites. i have not seen "illegal content thumbnails" on 0chan. but perhaps a person who lives in country A sees more illegal content than a person who live sin country B since different countries impose different laws on their citizens.

although if i remember right, 0chan Porn uses optional files for their different boards. if you don't opt to download something you know is bad, you should be safe, right?

if you are running a proxy service, you should be aware that 0chan Porn is not the only porn site ran on this network, and it is likely not the only site which does not have an "age disclaimer" on the front page if that is a legal requirement to have on your website where you live.

> [nothing](#comment_10_1GnKQZXGc51J9spdsMMXxJizM41LXeKEBz): i don't know how the site's work excatly but the thing is 0chan porn has child pornography on it and that's what i'm trying to warn people about..

im really sorry, i was just under the impression this was common knowledge. i have had it blacklisted on my zeronet instance for a long time, and if someone runs a public proxy service he should do the same.

i'm just baffled that a topic was created asking if it should be removed from his proxy service or not. op should try to be more in touch with what's going on in zeronet, as it seems he has been proxying a cp site on the public www internet for quite some time now. he wants his "concerns to be addressed" but i think he would have addressed them a lot more quickly if he just went to the site and saw it was hosting illegal content.

then he posts on zerome what i can only interpret as a public service announcement demanding zite owners on zeronet to run their site in a certain way when it's really not his place to tell others how to run a website. if you are mirroring content on the public www internet, it is YOUR responsibility to make sure you aren't hosting anything illegal. other parties are not responsible for your legal problems. they are only responsible for their own.

but yes, 0chan Porn (not to be confused with the separate service 0chan), is a host for child pornography and it is to the best of my knowledge not moderated, and they do not ask users if they are 18 before entering, and they do not have a "all models on the site are 18+" disclaimer on the site. if that is a problem for you, i would highly recommend not visiting it or blacklisting the site. if you host it on a public proxy service to the www internet, i would highly recommend not doing so.

if a site operator doesn't want to put an age disclaimer on their website they will choose not to do so, and that is their right. the legality of not having a disclaimer depends entirely on the legal jurisdiction they reside in, but if a website is distributed, and not hosted on a server in a specific country, there may not be any legal requirements to put a disclaimer on there.

additionally, on a website that consists entirely of user submitted content, it is dishonest and counterintuitive to proclaim "We have verified that all persons appearing in nudie photographs submitted to our site were 18 years or older at the time the nudie picture was made." How would they even begin to verify this information? Unless the user who submits the photograph also submits the contact information (dox) of the individual, there is no way to reach out to them and verify their age at the time the picture was taken.

it's one thing to prohibit child pornography on your site, but it's a whole nother thing to verify the legal age of all participants in pornographic footage submitted to your site by the general public.

> [mrsrobotmobile](#comment_2_1HsgZpHaZ5BRUK5qr2YMWnubgKyNuSqokH): Obviously.. We won't ever be able to weed out all the apples..but it would be great if more zite owners were proactive about moderating their content. Just so that zeronet proxy owners can host a few porn sites here and there.. and let adults enjoy themselves without too much drama..without having to blacklist Every single site with the keywords Porn in it. [...]

Have you considered that that particular site operator wished to have that kind of content posted?
And while members of the ZeroNet community SHOULD be proactive and do what is best for the "community", it is also true that ZeroNet is a public tool that anyone can pick up and use to do whatever they want with. ZeroNet is not and should not be designed to weed out "bad apples" in that sense.

This means everyone else has to be the responsible and proactive. If you run a service that hosts content published on sites you don't have the ability to control, you have to be a defensive administrator and be proactive to prevent abuse of your service. That includes knowing what the hell you are mirroring and making available to everyone else.

Other viewers likely ARE seeding content they don't know about. They may have since deleted or "believed" they deleted it without realizing some files are still being seeded. These are the risks people may or may not know they are taking when they run ZeroNet. Perhaps nofish needs to be more proactive in educating people about these risks?

At the end of the day though, anyone can publish anything on ZeroNet, and ZeroNet is designed to make it very hard for what is published to be censored and made unavailable. You may consider yourself a member of the community surrounding ZeroNet, but someone who may wish to make a CP website may not think themselves as belonging to a community, and they will likely act in such a way that is harmful to the public image of the network.

You cannot stop them from doing that because ZeroNet is designed to enable them to do that. All that you can do is think and act proactively with this threat model in mind.

Furthermore, if there even WAS the ability to stop anyone from publishing CP on ZeroNet, doing so would be in direct conflict with ZeroNet's goals of being uncensorable and accessible to everyone.

> [styromaniac](#comment_315_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I've since clarified that I meant 0chan Porn. The thumbnails are not optional files.

That makes a lot more sense now. I had not been there since I originally blacklisted it and forgot or did not realize that the thumbnails were not optional files, although I thought entire boards were, and different types of content were hosted on different boards which you had to opt in to. Either way, anyone sensitive to this content is better off just blacklisting it so they don't stumble on it again by accident.

> [cracknut](#comment_2_18YwvP36gwZKnk1KfQ8Rb3ca8xJpuzJBPo): Shit like this is what scares me about Zeronet. Inadvertently stumbling on child porn and then having it either in your cache or just being marked as a peer. You're fucked. How the hell are we supposed to protect ourselves?

this is one of ZeroNet's biggest faults. frankly i do not believe network was designed with that kind of abuse in mind. now, if the content was encrypted during transmission and encrypted when saved on your hard drive to give the user plausible deniability at the bare minimum, things would be a little bit better. but as of right now, the answer is that you simply have to know every bit and byte you have cached and are helping seed.

it is for this reason that i have become hesitant to automatically download and seed content on any website or service on the network without first reviewing what kind of content it is.

it might be wise to stuff your ZeroNet installs in an encrypted container in addition to running in tor-only mode.

1513230190_1K8XkWirXhKSqE3t6WfcjbUcuSTCa.body:
> [akito](#comment_401_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): Putting Facebook into ZeroNet would be like putting a nazi into a group of scientists. It just won't fit.

nazis and scientists got along really well actually

> [akito](#comment_403_1F8omDpXyPsBfd9CBJ91o4Wv1AA2KxqMEY): That's what they try to make you think. Obviously the "scientists" were doing a lot of unnecessary experiments, because they actually had no idea what they were doing. That wasn't scientific.

is that what they are teaching in school?

1513428479_1EQuGEmS5J8SQ1xA6MM9KfubBb71u.body:
i'm very confused by this topic.

are we asking for censorship on ZeroNet or are we asking for tools that provide more extensive control for ZeroNet Proxy operators?

unmoderated content on the network is a feature, not a bug.

> [krixano](#comment_251_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu): It says Proxy in the title. Proxy owners should be able to manage the zites that are on their server. Currently they can block all new zites, but that is not friendly to the users. Proxy owners can get into serious trouble from their hosting provider or government for having illegal content. If you want to view illegal content, use your own client instead of potentially getting someone else into trouble because of it.

i did not know the proxy stuff was an officially developed component of zeronet, thus some confusion. i had just assumed people were setting up public proxies on their own. people who want to run proxy services for zeronet would definitely need proper tools to protect themselves and prevent abuse of their services and all of that good stuff.

My only other post in this topic was a request for clarification.

I have never once stated any opposition to any feature to be implemented in a ZeroNet "Proxy" Client, and have committed no greater sin than expressing my ignorance of its existence.

If what you desire are fewer opponents, I would suggest you start working toward that by checking your fucking attitude.
